results.title: We're no angels
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Pat Duggan and Michael Curtiz
results.brief_description: Set in French Guiana, three convicts escape from the notorious prison on Devil’s Island and hide amongst the colonists. In need of clothing and money, the three make plans to rob a milliner, Felix, and his family. The trio are deterred from their larcenous intents when they develop a fondness for the family. Discovering that Felix is on the verge of bankruptcy, the convicts offer their services as household help. Matters are further complicated when they discover that Felix’s wealthy cousin arrives to audit the books. Cast includes: Humphrey Bogart, Aldo Ray, Peter Ustinov, Joan Bennett and Basil Rathbone.

results.title: Way down east [DVD]
results.brief_description: A country girl is tricked into a fake marriage by a lecherous playboy. He deserts her when she becomes pregnant. After the death of the baby she seeks refuge in the house of a puritanical squire. The melodramatic cliche of the original play is transformed, suffused with the timelessness of myth by Griffith and the principal players. The extraordinary delicacy and intensity of Gish is well complemented by the playing of Barthelmess as the country boy. The final scenes of fragility against the elements in the blizzard and on the icefloe (filmed at some risk to Gish and Barthelmess) is a tour-de-force of staging, composition and editing. Based on the play by Lottie Blair Parker, William Brady and Joseph R. Grisner. Cast includes Lillian Gish, Richard Barthelmess and Lowell Sherman. With musical soundtrack recorded in 1928 by Louis Silvers. This version was fully restored by film historian David Shepard.

results.title: Watership down
results.brief_description:
One dim moonlit night, a small band of rabbits leave the comfort and safety of their warren and set out on a long and dangerous journey after a premonition of a terrible disaster that will overtake them if they stay. None of them knows where they are heading, or the dangers they will face in their search for a new warren where they can live in peace. Adapted from Richard Adams’ modern classic.
Voiced by actors including: John Hurt, Richard Briers, Ralph Richardson, Denholm Elliott, Zero Mostel, Nigel Hawthorne, Michael Hordern, Joss Ackland.

results.title: Waterloo bridge
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Sidney A. Franklin and Mervyn LeRoy
results.brief_description: Starring Vivian Leigh and Robert Taylor, this is a tragic tale. An army officer marries a ballerina. When he is reported missing his family ignores her and she sinks into prostitution. A ‘weepie’ which has had mixed reviews over time, but still remains very popular.

results.title: Water drops on burning rocks = Gouttes d'eau sur pierres brulantes
results.creator_credit: Fidelite Productions, Les Films Alain Sarde, Eurospace, Olivier Delbosc, Marc Missonnier, Alain Sarde and Francois Ozon
results.brief_description: Based on Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s play “Tropfen auf hiesse Steine” this richly perverse and very funny sex comedy stars Bernard Giraudeau as Leopold, an ultra successful and ultra conservative businessman who seduces the young Franz. But when Franz moves in, all expectations are overturned when it is Leopold who refuses to compromise to Franz’s old fashioned sense of morality and domesticity. Franz turns to his ex-girlfriend for comfort but she too ends up falling for Leopold’s cold seductive charms. Their bizarre menage-a-trois is then interrupted when Leopold’s ex, Vera, a male to female transsexual, comes for a visit. Rather than needlessly “opening up” the original play’s stagebound scenes, Ozon instead creates a slightly surreal enclosed space in which the four actors are able to create characters both bizarre but also strikingly realistic. The crisp, imaginative direction allows for both the humour of the original play, as well as its cruelty, to be fully expressed. A wonderfully fresh and stylish comedy of manners, “Water Drops on Burning Rocks” is a splendid example of how queer cinema can transgress both heterosexual and homosexual normative ideals. Cast includes Malik Zidi, Ludivine Sagnier and Anna Levine. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Washington square
results.creator_credit: Hollywood Picture, Caravan Pictures, Alchemy Filmworks, Roger Birnbaum, Julie Bergman Sender and Agnieszka Holland
results.brief_description: Jennifer Jason Leigh stars as Catherine Sloper, a ‘plain’ and socially inept young woman with a domineering father who blames his daughter for the death of his wife during childbirth. Incapable of expressing any love or tenderness towards his daughter, Dr. Sloper (Albert Finney) is immediately suspicious of the handsome young suitor who starts pursuing her. Believing that Morris Townsend’s (Ben Chaplin) interest in Catherine is motivated by her wealth, Dr. Sloper does everything in his power to forbid the liaison. Willing to surrender her inheritance in order to marry Morris, Catherine gradually realises that nobody wants her to make this sacrifice. Also stars Maggie Smith and Judith Ivey. Based upon the novel by Henry James which was filmed as ‘The Heiress’ by William Wyler. Screenplay by Carol Doyle. Photographed by Jerzy Zielinski. Edited by David Siegel. Music by Jan P. Kaczmarek.

results.title: Warm nights on a slow moving train
results.creator_credit: Western Pacific Films, Ross Dimsey, Patric Juillet and Bob Ellis
results.brief_description: Wendy Hughes plays an art teacher employed at a Catholic girls’ convent school from Monday to Friday. At weekends she rides the overnight express train between Sydney and Melbourne as a prostitute in order to keep her addict brother supplied with morphine. Every week she changes her appearance, mannerisms, and personality, luring male clients who always pay and leave by 3 a.m. However, an intelligence agent (Colin Friels) becomes her lover and they team up to murder a politician on the train. Wendy Hughes exudes sensuality, power and passion in the lead role.

results.title: War of the colossal beast
results.creator_credit: American International Pictures (AIP) and Bert I. Gordon
results.brief_description: In this sequel to “The Amazing colossal man” (Bert I. Gordon, 1957), the gigantic beast of the original is feared to have survived his almighty fall, and now quite deranged, to be posing an even greater threat. Incoherent and hideously disfigured, the monster is located in Mexico, but after thwarting the authorities attempts to tame him, goes on the rampage. Director and effects maestro Bert I. Gordon specialised in B-Grade 1950s horror, and does not disappoint here, even adding extra dazzle to the finale which is presented in colour.

results.title: War and peace
results.creator_credit: Ponti-De Laurentis, Paramount Pictures, Dino De Laurentiis and King Vidor
results.brief_description: Based on Leo Tolstoy’s 20th Century masterpiece, it took a decade of preparation and two years of filming to produce this classic version. The personal stories of many characters, love affairs, and philosophies are woven throughout this massive and intricate tapestry of Russia during Napoleon’s invasion at the turn of the 19th Century. With great attention to detail and historical accuracy, this epic becomes an unforgettable document as well as a highly moving drama.

results.title: Wall Street
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Edward Pressman and Oliver Stone
results.brief_description: Skinny neckties and double-breasted suits adorn Wall Street, which follows the path of Bud Fox (Charlie Sheen) into a milieu of corporate capitalism. He soon realises to stay in this new world with high-powered corporate espionage player Gordon Gekko (Michael Douglas) he must break a few rules. Gekko represents one of three father figures for Fox, the other two being his real father and his boss at the broking firm, all of whom give him constant advice. However, Fox’s overwhelming desire for gold cufflinks and brick-like cellular phones steer him down the path of corruption and greed and he soon realises the price of the pursuit of overnight success. Director Oliver Stone captures the hectic hum of the commerce world and encapsulates the greed that is synonymous with the rise of capitalism in the 1980s. Michael Douglas received an Oscar for Best Actor at the 1987 Academy Awards for his role as Gekko.
